organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to support the implementation of Canada’s Indo-Pacific Strategy and additional salary funding received to cover compensation adjustments associated with collective agreements in 2023-24. The variance is also due to reallocation of resources from the Community Safety core responsibility to the National Security core responsibility to support the Cyber Security Cooperation Program. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents (FTE) in 2023-24 is primarily due to regular attrition offset by additional FTEs required to support the implementation of Canada's Indo-Pacific Strategy.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels of the Building Safer Communities Fund based on forecasted funding needs.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates for the Initiative to Take Action against Gun and Gang Violence (ITAAGGV) renewal.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned funding and planned FTEs from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the completion of the design and development phase of the compensation program for prohibited assault-style firearms. The decrease in planned funding is also attributable to the maturation of the funding requested to eliminate the Memorial Grant Program backlog and accommodate projected near-term growth in program applications.

The decrease in planned funding from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the funding requested to eliminate the Memorial Grant Program backlog and accommodate projected near-term growth in program applications as well as the maturation of the funding for the Nation’s Capital Extraordinary Policing Costs Program. The decrease in planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels for the enhancement of the Canada’s Firearm Control Framework as well as for the Memorial Grant Program for First Responders. The decrease in planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels for the enhancement of the Canada’s Firearm Control Framework as well as for the Memorial Grant Program for First Responders.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates for the Newfoundland and Labrador’s New Adult Corrections Facility Project, safety and security-related expenses for the December 2022 United Nations Biodiversity Conference (Conference of the Parties 15) and the July 2022 Papal visit, and to support the assault-style firearms compensation program (ASFCP). This is offset by a lapse under the Memorial Grant Program for First Responders due to lower than anticipated number of cases by the program. The intention is to transfer the full amount of this lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2023-24 is primarily due to additional FTEs required to support the assault-style firearms compensation program (ASFCP).

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned funding from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the Anti-Money Laundering Action, Coordination and Enforcement (ACE) Team and the National Strategy to Combat Human Trafficking and a decrease in funding levels for the initiative to build capacity to address drug impaired driving in Canada. The decrease in planned FTEs is primarily attributable to the maturation of the funding for the Anti-Money Laundering Action, Coordination and Enforcement (ACE) Team.

The decrease in planned funding from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the contribution funding for the Implementation of an initiative to build capacity to address drug impaired driving in Canada.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of lapses under the Drug Impaired Driving Initiative and the National Strategy for Protecting Children from Sexual Exploitation Online within the Contribution Program to Combat Serious and Organized Crime (CPCSOC).

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2023-24 falls within the normal course of business.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels for the First Nations and Inuit Policing Facilities Program and the maturation of the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program. Funding for these programs might be renewed at a later time, based on funding needs.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of a transfer to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police for the First Nations Community Policing Service. Furthermore, there are lapses under the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program and the First Nations and Inuit Policing Facilities program mainly due to implementation delays, delays from external partners and slower than expected project delivery timelines. The intention is to transfer the lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The increase in planned funding from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to an increase in funding level for the expansion of the Aboriginal Community Safety Planning Initiative and for the Indigenous Community Corrections Initiative.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of lapses under the Indigenous Community Corrections Initiative and the Aboriginal Community Safety Development Contribution Program. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2023-24 falls within the normal course of business.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned FTEs from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the funding for Wildfire and Flood Resilience and for the National Risk Profile.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of new funding received through the Supplementary Estimates to enhance natural disaster resilience and for Canada’s National Adaptation Strategy. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2023-24 is primarily attributed to increased policy capacity in response to growing pressure to deliver on Emergency Management activities due to the frequent and severe impacts of climate change needs, and incremental funding that was received to enhance natural disaster resilience and Canada’s National Adaptation Strategy.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the completion of the capital investment for the relocation and accommodations for the Government Operations Centre.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of a transfer of funding from the current fiscal year to next fiscal year 2024-25 for the relocation and accommodations of the Government Operations Centre project. This is offset by additional salary funding received to cover compensation adjustments associated with collective agreements in 2023-24. The variance between actual and planned Full-Time Equivalents in 2023-24 is primarily due to new salary funding received through the Supplementary Estimates and additional FTEs required to enhance natural disaster resilience and to extend the Humanitarian Workforce program.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned funding from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is primarily attributable to the settlement of existing liabilities for past events under the Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements program in 2023-24.

The decrease in planned funding from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is primarily attributable to the settlement of existing liabilities for past events under the Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements program in 2024-25 and the program supporting the Canadian Red Cross’s urgent relief efforts to support British Columbia's response and recovery efforts following the 2021 atmospheric flooding and wildfires events.
variance_explanation: The variance between actual and planned spending in 2023-24 is primarily the result of lapsed funding under the Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements Contribution Program and the Canadian Red Cross’s urgent relief efforts related to COVID-19, floods and wildfires program. The intention is to transfer lapsed funding for use in future fiscal years.

organization: Department of Public Works and Government Services
planning_explanation:

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
variance_explanation:
Actual expenditures exceeded planned spending by approximately $12.7 million. This variance is explained by higher-than-expected spending in the Québec economic development program (QEDP), the Community Futures program (CFP) and a reclassification of an initiative. 
Spending was higher than anticipated in the Québec economic development program, because CED had to adapt it investments to the changing economic context, regional needs and government priorities. Regular program funds were reallocated to meet greater needs.
During the year, the agreement for the Community Futures program was renewed, resulting in slightly higher costs than anticipated at the start of the year. 
The initiative for the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) had been planned under the targeted or temporary support program at the beginning of the year but was reclassified under the Vitality of communities program during the year due to the nature of the project.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
variance_explanation:
Actual expenditures exceeded planned spending by approximately $57.6 million. This variance is mainly due to the deferral of several projects by one year following the extension of economic recovery initiatives, and to the approval of new initiatives. 
The initiatives for which funds have been deferred from 2022-2023 to 2023-2024 are the Major Festivals and Events Support Initiative (MFESI), the Canadian Community Revitalization Fund (CCRF), the Aerospace Regional Recovery Initiative (ARRI) and the Quebec Infrastructure Development Initiative (IDI). These initiatives have been postponed, as several projects could not materialize in 2022-2023 due to lack of manpower, delays in supply chains and inflation. 
New initiatives received during the year were the Hurricane Fiona Recovery Fund (HFRF) and the Tourism Growth Program (TGP).

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
variance_explanation: CED is constantly adapting to the changing economic context, regional needs and government priorities. We spent slightly more than planned. Funds were therefore reallocated where the needs were greatest.

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
variance_explanation: CED spent approximately $3.8 million more than anticipated on internal services. During 2023-2024, many collective agreements affecting internal services were renewed, thereby increasing associated expenses. In addition, a number of initiatives were approved during the year, such as the Hurricane Fiona Recovery Fund (HFRF), the Tourism Growth Program (TGP) and the Regional Economic Growth through Innovation (REGI) top-up. An operating carryover was also received during the year, part of which was spent by internal departments.

planning_explanation:
The net change in planned spending and FTE between fiscal years is mainly due to changes in financial profiles related to:
•	the partnership between LAC, Ottawa Public Library and the City of Ottawa for the Ādisōke project;
•	the initiative to implement the federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools (2022–2023 to 2024–2025); and
•	the initiative to implement the Federal Pathway to Address Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, announced in Budget 2021 (2021–2022 to 2024–2025).
variance_explanation:
The variation in actual and planned resources in 2023-24 is explained by:
- Implementing the LGBT Purge Class Action Final Settlement Agreement (2023-24 to 2026-27);
- The partnership between LAC and the Ottawa  Public Library for the Ādisōke project; and
- Salary adjustments following the ratification of collective agreements.

The net change in planned spending between fiscal years is mainly due to changes in financial profiles related to:
•	the initiative to support the access to information and litigation support function (2022–23 to 2027–28);
•	the initiative to implement the federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools, announced in Budget 2022 (2022–23 to 2024–25); and
•	the initiative to implement the Federal Pathway to Address Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, announced in Budget 2021 (2021–22 to 2024–25).

The net change in planned full-time equivalents between fiscal years is mainly due to changes in resources related to:
•	the initiative to support the access to information and litigation support function (2022–23 to 2027–28);
•	the initiative to implement the federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools, announced in Budget 2022 (2022–23 to 2024–25); and
•	the initiative to implement the Federal Pathway to Address Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls, announced in Budget 2021 (2021–22 to 2024–25).
variance_explanation:
The varation in actual and planned resources for 2023-24 is explained mainly by:
- the evolution of resources related to the initiative to support the Access to Information and ligitation support functions to address the recommendations of the Office of the Information Commissioner's report (2022-23 to 2027-2028); and
- Reallocation of resources to initatives and activities within LAC's other core responsibilities.

planning_explanation:
The 2022-23 forecast spending represents an increase of $164.8 thousand compared to 2021-2022 total expenditures. This planned increase is mostly explained by the retro and in-year compensation adjustments for executives and senior leaders.  

The reason for the decrease in the amount from 2022-23 to 2023-2024 is that 2023-2024 and future years do not include any operating budget carry-forward, only the Main Estimates.

The total number of FTEs forecasted by the end of 2022-2023 is aligned exactly with the 49 FTEs planned in the 2022-2023 Departmental Plan. The table above shows a realignment of FTEs between the program and internal services. This adjustment was a necessity, made according to organizational priorities. The Committee intends to remain at approximately 49 FTEs over the next three fiscal years. Maintaining a proactive staffing plan and implementing proactive recruitment and talent retention strategies are crucial.
variance_explanation: Additional funding was secured through supplementary estimates for the payment of the compensation adjustments. The Main Estimates did not include any amounts for operating carry forward, which was later added to the Committee’s total authorities available for use.	The Committee received temporary funding in Supplementary Estimates from the Department of National Defence (DND) to increase its capacity to produce F&R reports in a timely manner.

planning_explanation:

The reason for the decrease in the amount from 2022-23 to 2023-2024 is that 2023-2024 and future years do not include any operating budget carry-forward, only the Main Estimates.

The total number of FTEs forecasted by the end of 2022-2023 is aligned exactly with the 49 FTEs planned in the 2022-2023 Departmental Plan. variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual resources in Internal Services is partially attributed to an increase in salary expenses due to compensation adjustments following the ratification of various collective agreements and updates to the terms and conditions of employment. Additionally, the Committee received temporary funding in Supplementary Estimates from the Department of National Defence to increase its capacity to produce F&R reports in a timely manner. Hiring more employees for the Committee’s program in 2023-24 resulted in additional FTE requirements in Internal Services to ensure the successful staffing and onboarding of new employees and to also ensure that the workplace could accommodate additional resources.

variance_explanation: Actual expenditures were higher as a result of the deferral of funds for Asset Maintenance Plan projects initiated in previous years and authorized during the year. The variations can also be explained by the fact that the NBC had planned a change in presentation of its planned expenditures to better inform decision-makers and the public, by allocating internal service expenditures to its program costs in order to demonstrate what it costs to carry out each program. This presentation was intended to better represent how resources are organized to contribute to core responsibilities and results. During the year under review, this allocation was not implemented in the financial system, and the financial presentation remained unchanged from previous years.

Actual expenditures were lower as a result of a deferral of funds, for projects postponed to 2024-2025.  It should be noted that for its planned expenditures, the NBC had planned a change in presentation to better inform decision-makers and the public, by allocating internal services expenditures to its program costs in order to demonstrate what it costs to deliver each program. This presentation was intended to better represent how resources are organized to contribute to core responsibilities and results. During the year under review, this allocation was not implemented in the financial system, and the financial presentation remained unchanged from previous years.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure and Communities Investment Stewardship and Delivery
variance_explanation: Although Housing, Infrastructure and Communities Canada's grants and contributions expenditures continued to increase in 2023-24 (from $4.3 billion in 2022-23 to $4.9 billion in 2023-24), some funding was unavailable for use given conditionality around certain projects, which is the primary cause of the variance between actual and planned spending. The variance between planned and actual FTEs is primarily due to new resources received through recent Federal Budgets to support resilient infrastructure in the face of a changing climate and the National Infrastructure Assessment.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure and Communities Investment Stewardship and Delivery
planning_explanation:
Variance in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is mainly attributable to the Samuel de Champlain Bridge for unresolved and unanticipated events from the Design-Build period. 

Variance in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the Gordie Howe International Bridge project for responsibilities related to the stewardship of Canadian lands and fulfil future legal obligations from past property transactions.
variance_explanation: The variance in planned and actual spending is primarily due to delays in ongoing work related to the Samuel De Champlain Bridge Corridor project. The variance in planned and actual FTEs is primarily due to new funding received through an off-cycle funding decision to support the completion of the negotiations to repatriate and rehabilitate the Quebec Bridge.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure and Communities Investment Stewardship and Delivery

variance_explanation: The variance in planned and actual spending is mainly attributable to the P3 Canada Fund program, which was accessed through the Supplementary Estimates process to facilitate the substantial completion of the Edmonton Light Rail Transit project. The variance in FTEs is attributable to a realignment of resources from policy to perform activities in support of investment and oversight.

core_responsibility: Public Infrastructure and Communities Investment Stewardship and Delivery

Variance in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 represents the transition from the growth phase in operational requirements including the change to a hybrid work model, as a result of the new funding and resources received through the Fall Economic Statement 2020 and Budget 2021, to ongoing works.

No FTEs are captured under Real Property given that INFC is not the owner of the space.
variance_explanation: The variance in planned and actual spending is attributable to planned office space optimization projects tied to departmental growth as a result of funding received through recent Federal Budgets and off-cycle funding decisions.

planning_explanation:
Variance in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 represents the transition from the growth phase in material as a result of the new funding and resources received through the Fall Economic Statement 2020 and Budget 2021, to ongoing works.

No FTEs are captured under Material as there are no dedicated teams responsible for this within INFC. The work is distributed across multiple functional areas.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
planning_explanation:
This spending pattern is a result of the decennial electoral boundaries redistribution cycle, which began in 2020–21 and is expected to finish in 2023–24.

The fluctuation in planned full-time equivalents is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.
variance_explanation:
The difference of $0.3 million (deficit) is largely explained by higher-than-expected costs for the completion of activities related to the revisions of electoral boundaries and the implementation of new collective bargaining agreements including the issuance of retroactive payments.

The difference of 2 full-time equivalents (deficit) is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
planning_explanation:
The fluctuation in planned spending over these fiscal years is mainly due to the reduction in the preparedness period for 2025–26 — the latest date for calling the 45th general election is September 2025 — and to the profile of investments in digital transformation priorities.

The fluctuation in planned full-time equivalents is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.
variance_explanation:
The difference of $3.9 million (surplus) is primarily due to investment plans in digital transformation priorities supporting this program were not fully developped at the time of Main Estimates therefore funding is being reprofiled to future fiscal years.

The difference of 41 full-time equivalents (deficit) is mainly due to the increase in preparation activities for the 45th general election.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer

variance_explanation:
The difference of $24.6 million (deficit) is primarily a result of increased preparation activities for the 45th general election and the cost to conduct six by-elections, which was not part of the agency’s Main Estimates.

The difference of 5 full-time equivalents (surplus) is mainly due to delays in staffing.

organization: Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
planning_explanation:
The fluctuation in planned spending over these fiscal years is mainly due to the reduction in the preparedness period for 2025–26 — the latest date for calling the 45th general election is September 2025 — and to the profile of investments in digital transformation priorities.

The fluctuation in planned full-time equivalents is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.
variance_explanation:
The difference of $13.1 million (deficit) is primarily due to the increased preparation activities for the 45th general election, increased investments in digital transformation priorities supporting Internal Services and the implementation of new collective agreements including the issuance of retroactive payments.

The difference of 67 full-time equivalents (deficit) is largely explained by the same reasons stated above.

organization: Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions
core_responsibility: Financial Institution and Pension Plan Regulation and Supervision
program_name: Risk Assessment and Intervention - Federally Regulated Financial Institutions
variance_explanation: OSFI’s 2023-24 planned spending for Risk Assessment and Intervention - Federally Regulated Financial Institutions, as presented in the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, was $99.8 million. Actual spending was $13.5 million higher due higher than planned economic adjustments related to union agreements and an earlier than expected ramp up of the addition of resources to implement the  strategic transformation initiatives outlined in the 2022-2025 Strategic Plan.

organization: Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions
core_responsibility: Financial Institution and Pension Plan Regulation and Supervision
program_name: Regulation and Guidance of Federally Regulated Financial Institutions
variance_explanation:
OSFI’s 2023-24 planned spending for regulation and guidance of Federally Regulated Financial Institutions, as presented in the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, was $31.3 million. Actual spending was $8.6 million higher due to higher than planned economic adjustments related to union agreements and an earlier than expected ramp up of the addition of resources to implement the  strategic transformation initiatives outlined in the 2022-2025 Strategic Plan.  

In fiscal year 2022-23 OSFI implemented OSFI's Blueprint for transformation and the 2022-25 Strategic Plan, which included FTE increases OSFI-wide.  When preparing the 2023-24 Departmental Plan, the ramp up in resources was expected to occur gradually. The actual ramp up occured faster than expected and lead to earlier growth in FTE's.  In addition, 2023-24 actuals include FTEs related to OSFI’s new Integrity and Security Mandate and the Data Collection Modernization project.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2024-25 planned spending is primarily due to variations in funding to implement the Tallurutiup Imanga National Marine Conservation Area Inuit Impact and Benefit Agreement as well as Enhanced Nature Legacy.

The decrease in 2025-26 planned spending is primarily due to variations in funding to implement the Tallurutiup Imanga National Marine Conservation Area Inuit Impact and Benefit Agreement, Enhanced Nature Legacy as well as the sunset of funding in 2024-25 to implement the Federal Framework to address the Legacy of Residential Schools.

The decrease in 2025-26 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of funding in 2024-25 to implement the Federal Framework to address the Legacy of Residential Schools.
variance_explanation: Actual FTEs for the Heritage Places Establishment Program is 25 FTEs or 16% lower than the 2023-24 planned FTEs.  This variance is primarily due to staffing delays.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
planning_explanation: The decrease in 2025-26 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of the temporary funding in 2024-25 for investments  in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability.  Parks Canada continues its efforts to ensure the long term financial sustainability of its asset portfolio.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
program_name: Heritage Places Promotion and Public Support
variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Heritage Places Promotion and Public Support Program is $42.2 million or 62% higher than the 2023-24 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to additional engagement and consultation activities, including collaboration with indigenous partners, to support program delivery, to advance the establishment of new protected areas and work related to the Enhanced Nature Legacy and Indian Residential Schools initiatives. The variance is also due to timing of new funding received after the planning exercise mainly related to funding for the ratification of new collective agreements.

variance_explanation: Actual spending for the Visitor Experience is $107.0 million or 26% higher than the 2023-24 planned spending. This variance is primarily due to additional expenditures incurred to support visitor services and facilities at various sites and from efforts to restore damaged infrastructure from Hurricane Fiona at sites in Atlantic Canada and the province of Quebec. The variance is also due to timing of new funding received after the planning exercise mainly related to funding for the ratification of a new collective agreement.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
program_name: Heritage Canals, Highways and Townsites Management
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending between 2023-24 and 2025-26 is mainly due to the variations in the temporary funding for investments in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability, which will continue until 2024-25 and sunset thereafter.   Parks Canada continues its efforts to ensure the long term financial sustainability of its asset portfolio.

The decrease in 2025-26 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of the temporary funding in  2024-25 for investments in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability as well as the sunset of funding of the Youth Employment and Skills Strategy.
variance_explanation:
Actual spending for the Heritage Canals, Highways and Townsite Management Program is $23.3 million or 11% lower than 2023-24 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to delays in delivering Asset Investment projects resulting from tendering challenges, supply chain constraints impacting the procurement of speciliazed materials for historic built assets and limited availablity of tradespeople and other skilled labor.

Actual FTEs for the Heritage Canals, Highways and Townsite Management Program is 36 FTEs or 11% lower than the 2023-24 planned FTEs.  This variance is primarily due to delays in delivering Asset Investment projects resulting from tendering challenges, supply chain constraints impacting the procurement of speciliazed materials for historic built assets and limited availablity of tradespeople and other skilled labor.

planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2025-26 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding in 2024-25 for:  the temporary funding for investments in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability, the Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan Phase IV, the funding to implement the Federal Framework to Address the Legacy of Residential Schools and the Youth Employment and Skills Strategy.

The decrease in 2025-26 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of the temporary funding in 2024-25 for investments in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability.
variance_explanation:
Actual spending for the Management and Oversight sub-program is $24.7 million or 82% higher than 2023-24 planned spending.  This variance is primarily due to increased assessment and planning work undertaken to develop the asset maintenance plan, internal reallocations to fund priorities related to the Real Property & Asset program and additional funds received after the planning exercise, mainly related to the ratification of a new collective agreement. 

Actual FTEs for  the Management and Oversight sub-program are 63 FTEs or 29% higher than planned FTEs in 2023-24. This variance is primarily due to increased planning work related to the Real Property & Asset program and internal reallocations to address other priorities.

Planned spending in 2023–24 was higher than Actual spending due to a lapse of funding for the Special Purpose Allotment (SPA) to conduct Public Hearings. The SPA can only be used to cover the costs of public hearings, such as external legal counsel and expert witnesses, etc. For purposes of forecasting planned spending, it is necessary to assume that the entire SPA funding will be spent because these expenditures are dependent on the number of hearings, and the length and complexity of the hearings held, which are difficult to predict. In 2023–24, spending on the SPA was $500,834 of the $4,463,360 available, a difference of $3,962,526. Any unspent amount is returned to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Actual spending in 2023–24 was higher than Planned spending as a result of compensation adjustments from collective agreements signed in 2023–24, an increase in the number of full-time equivalents (FTEs), and a corresponding rise in Employee Benefits Payments (EBP). Spending on information technology equipment also contributed to this difference.

variance_explanation:

This variance was partially offset by incremental expenditures related to compensation agreements, as well as incremental cost for the Grant to Compensate Members of the RCMP for Injuries Received in the Performance of Duty
The variance is related to incremental expenditures related to compensation agreements, as well as incremental in-year funding for new initiatives not included in the Departmental Plan.

The variance is related to in-year increases to staffing levels not included in the Departmental Plan.

The variance between planned FTEs and actual FTEs is mainly due to in-year increases to right-size the Functional Area, which was not included in the Departmental Plan.
The variance in spending versus the Departmental Plan was due to incremental in-year funding for RCMP initiatives.

The majority of variance is related to Planned Staffing within RCMP Operational IM/IT Services,  and actual staffing occurs within Information Management Services and Information Technology Services under Internal Services. When taking into account these three Functional Areas, the variance is minimal. 
The increase in spending versus the Departmental Plan was due to pressures funded internally in-year.

The variance is mainly due to the process of reporting inventory expenditures in the Warehouse accounts in Materiel Services, prior to distribution of the inventory  and corresponding expenditures to operational program areas.

organization: Royal Canadian Mounted Police External Review Committee
core_responsibility: Independent review of RCMP employment matters
planning_explanation:
The ERC’s work with the portfolio department and central agencies to address its permanent funding requirements has resulted in the ERC receiving additional permanent ongoing funding in the Fall of fiscal year 2020-21. This additional funding directly supports the integrity of the appeal case review program at the ERC.

The ERC’s planned complement of resources from 2023-24 and ongoing is 33 FTEs. The increase of FTEs since 2020-21 is attributed to increasing capacity and the creation of new positions as a result of additional permanent ongoing funding received in the Fall of 2020-21.
variance_explanation:
In 2009-10, given the focused nature of its program and associated resources, the ERC was granted an exemption from separately reporting on Internal Services. As a result, Planned Spending and Full-time equivalents (FTE) count in the table above are presented for the entire organization. 

Following the approval of Treasury Board Submission and allocation increase in 2021, the ERC adjusted its processes to initiate respective program and internal services financial reporting. Consequently, for the fiscal year 2023-24, the Actual Spending and FTE count is specific to Independent review of RCMP employment matters core responsibility. Since this is a year of transition, the Planned and Actual Spending and FTE count cannot be compared.

planning_explanation: Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Also reflected in all three years are planned resources for several initiatives from Budget 2021 as well as new initiatives from Budget 2022.

Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Also reflected in all three years are planned resources for several initiatives from Budget 2021 as well as new initiatives from Budget 2022 for which funding decreases from 2023–24 to 2025–26.
variance_explanation: The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of an increase in resources for new initiatives from Budget 2023, including the Canadian Dental Care Plan, Building a World-class Health Data System for Canadians and the Action Plan for Official Languages. Additionally, the increase includes compensation from the ratification of collective agreements and for cloud operations initiative.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned resources from 2023–24 to future years relates largely to the cyclical nature of the Census Program, as funding for the 2021 Census of Population and 2021 Census of Agriculture winds down. Funding for the 2026 Census of Population and the 2026 Census of Agriculture has not yet been approved but is expected to be approved in 2023–24, with the first year of funding being 2023–24.
variance_explanation: The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of funding for the Census of Population and Census of Agriculture that was received through the Supplementary Estimates 2023-24. Also included is a planned reprofile to future years to provide Statistics Canada the financial flexibility required to successfully conduct the 2026 Census cycle.

planning_explanation:
Statistics Canada is funded by two sources: direct parliamentary appropriations and cost-recovery activities. Statistics Canada has the authority to generate $120 million annually in respendable revenue, related to two streams: statistical surveys and related services, and custom requests and workshops. A large portion of this respendable revenue comes from federal departments to fund specific statistical projects.

Planned net budgetary spending represents statutory funding attributed to the program.
variance_explanation: The net spending for this program is related to non-respendable items such as the Employee Benefit Plan (EBP).  An increase in resources for additional cost recovery work contributed to the increase in actual FTEs versus planned FTEs.

planning_explanation:
Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. 

Planned resources include funding related to the Integrated Strategic Plan.
variance_explanation:
The increase in actual versus planned spending is mainly the result of salary price increases and retroactive pay received from the ratification of collective agreements. Also included is an increase in resources for cloud operations initiative. 
The increases are partially offset by budget carried forward to 2024-25, as well as internal investments approved through the agency's Integrated Business Planning Process. This approach enables the agency to support its cyclical programs and invest in its integrated strategic plans.

planning_explanation:
Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for the delivery of ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. 

The decrease in planned resources from 2023–24 to future years is related to how the agency strategically manages its investments. Investments are managed centrally, by priority, within the Centres of Expertise program. Investment funding from past years will end in future years, while new investment decisions will be finalized only later in the year.

program_name: Expenditure Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews
planning_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending from 2023-24 to 2025-26 for Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews is mainly attributable to the funding for Application Modernization Initiative, which is sunsetting in 2023-24 and damages caused by the Phoenix Pay System and the late implementation of the 2014 collective agreements, which is sunsetting in 2025-26. 

The decrease in full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for Funding for “Advancing Gender Equality” and “Expanding the Work of the LGBTQ2+ Secretariat” as provided by Budget 2019 and funding for the Implementing Proactive Pay Equity in the Federal Public Service, which sunset in 2023-24 and 2024-25. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews program is mainly attributable to the transfer of central vote funding to other government departments and agencies.

program_name: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives
planning_explanation: No explanation provided
variance_explanation:
The increase in planned spending for the Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements and employee benefit plans within the Strategic Communications and Ministerial Affairs Sector.

The decrease in full-time equivalents for the Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives program is mainly attributable to minor vacancies in the Strategic Communications and Ministerial Affairs Sector for the web renewal initiative.

planning_explanation: No explanation provided
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents for the Canadian Digital Service program is attributable to the Order in Council 2023-0784 that transferred the program to Employment and Social Development Canada.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Public Service Accessibility is mainly attributable to funding to renew the Office of Public Service Accessibility, funding to support a healthy, diverse, inclusive and accessible public service, and the Centralized Enabling Workplace Fund, all of which are sunsetting in 2023-24. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending for the Public Service Accessibility program is mainly attributed to internal reallocations.

planning_explanation:
The increase of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for the Comptrollership Program is attributable to the funding to advance clean fuels markets and carbon capture, utilization, and storage technologies in Canada. The decrease of planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 for the Comptrollership Program is attributable to reductions in transfers from various organizations to the Treasury Board Secretariat for contributions to the Greening Government Fund. The initiative is subject to the renewal process. 

The decrease in full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 is mainly attributable to the sunsetting of funding to establish the Centre of Expertise for Real Property to improve federal asset management. The decrease in full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to funding for the Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan: Phase IV and funding to increase opportunities in Federal procurement for Indigenous-led businesses, which are sunsetting in 2024-25.
variance_explanation:
The decrease in planned spending for the Comptrollership Program is mainly attributable to funding for the Greening Government Fund for low carbon fuels and reduced carbon emissions initiatives that is either transferred to other government departments or lapsed at year end.

The increase in full-time equivalents is mainly attributable to three branches of the Office of the Comptroller General. The largest increase was seen for the Financial Management Transformation project, which received additional funding. The Acquired Services and Assets Sector saw increases in the Investment Planning and Project Management division, and the Community Management Office. Lastly, the Financial Management Sector saw increases within the Financial Policy and Community Development division.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for the Digital Government Program is attributable to the Access to Information Review and Action Plan, which is sunsetting in 2023-24. The initiative is subject to the renewal process. The decrease of planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is attributable to internal reallocations.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full-time equivalents for the Digital Government program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements, funding for the cyber security of government operations, and funding to provide continued leadership in cloud governance to help departments in their transition to cloud technologies.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Public Service Employer Payments is attributable to the funding requirements for the Public Service Insurance plans, the Public Service & Disability Insurance Plan and funding for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Life and Disability Insurance Plan. The increase of planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 for Public Service Employer Payments is attributable to funding for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Life and Disability Insurance Plan.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending for the Public Service Employer Payments program is mainly attributable to additional funding for public service insurance plans and programs.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for the Employer Program is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding for the development of a new inclusive language training framework for the federal public service, which sunsets in 2023-24 and funding for Implementing Proactive Pay Equity in the Federal Public Service, which sunsets in 2024-25. The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2024-25 to 2025-26 for the Employer Program is mainly attributable to funding for Implementing Proactive Pay Equity in the Federal Public Service, which is sunsetting in 2024-25. These initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation:
The increase in planned spending for the Employer program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements, critical operating requirements for the Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer, Phoenix stabilization and HR-to-Pay initiatives, the Action Plan for Black Public Servants, funding to address workplace harassment, discrimination, and violence in the federal public service, and funding for the Joint Learning Program.

The increase in full-time equivalents is primarily attributable to several divisions within the Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer: Strategic Direction and Digital Solutions, People and Culture, and Employee Relations and Compensation. Additionally, the Phoenix Claims Office has also contributed to the increase in full-time equivalents.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents (FTEs) from 2024-25 to 2025-26 for Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding for the extension of Targeted Regulatory Reviews, External Advisory Committee on Regulatory Competitiveness, which is sunsetting in 2024-25. This initiative is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation:
The increase in planned spending for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements.

The decrease in full-time equivalents for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to minor fluctuations across divisions within the Regulatory Affairs Sector.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2025-26 for the Management and Oversight Services is mainly attributable to funding for corporate costs as a result of new initiatives.
variance_explanation:
The increase in planned spending for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements, and increased spending within the Priorities and Planning Sector and the Strategic Communications and Ministerial Affairs Sector for access to information, and parliamentary and cabinet affairs.

The decrease in full-time equivalents for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to minor vacancies in various sectors.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2025-26 for the Communications Services program is attributable to various minor sunsetting initiatives. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full-time equivalents for the Communications Services program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements, funding for corporate costs from new initiatives, and internal reallocations to support salary requirements.

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2024-25 for Legal Services is mainly attributable to funding for Implementing Proactive Pay Equity in the Federal Public Service. This initiative is subject to the renewal process.
variance_explanation:

variance_explanation: The increase in planned spending and full-time equivalents for the Financial Management Services program is mainly attributable to funding for collective agreements and internal reallocations to support salary requirements.

variance_explanation: The decrease in planned spending and full-time equivalents for the Information Management Services program is mainly attributable to internal reallocations.

planning_explanation: The decrease of planned spending from 2023-24 to 2025-26 for Real Property Management Services is mainly attributable to various minor sunsetting initiatives. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

program_name: Public Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
variance_explanation:
SPENDING: 
The difference between 2023-24 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:

• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for:
 - health human resources; 
 - Indigenous distinctions-based mental wellness and trauma-informed health and cultural supports (Budget 2021);
 - a transfer from the Public Health Agency of Canada for testing of sexually transmitted and blood-borne infections in remote communities;
 - the implementation of the Inuit Tuberculosis Elimination Framework (Budget 2023);
 - the First Nations Health Authority; and
 - Canada’s National Adaptation Strategy. 

• an allocation of funding:
 - related to compensation and the reform to the First Nations Child and Family Services Program and Jordan’s Principle Initiative; and
 -  to meet departmental priorities.

•  the deferral of funding to future years for:
 -  costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs; and 
 -  a mercury care home for Asubpeeschoseewagong Netum Anishinabek and a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations.
These funds could not be spent in 2023-24 and are reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

FTE:
The variance in FTE utilization within First Nations and Inuit Health programs is to meet overall health needs for members of First Nations and Inuit communities and address health programs priorities and requirements.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING:

The difference between 2023-24 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:

•  the deferral of funding to future years for a mercury care home for Asubpeeschoseewagong Netum Anishinabek and a mercury wellness centre for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations. The variance in FTE utilization within First Nations and Inuit Health programs is to meet overall health needs for members of First Nations and Inuit communities and address health programs priorities and requirements.

program_name: Jordan's Principle and the Inuit Child First Initiative
planning_explanation:
SPENDING: The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for the continued implementation of Jordan's Principle and Inuit Child First Initiative; and 
* a decrease in funding for the reforms to the Jordan’s Principle program. 

FTE: The variance in FTE utilization is due to decrease in funding sources and a sunsetting item:
* sunset (at the end of 2023-24) of Funding for the Continued Implementation of Jordan’s Principle and Supporting Inuit Children (Budget 2019); 
* sunset (at the end of 2023-24) of funding to support individual compensation, capital expenditures, and immediate reforms of First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle.
variance_explanation:
SPENDING:
The difference between 2023-24 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:

• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle; and
• an allocation of funding to meet departmental priorities.

FTE:
The variance in FTE utilization is because of increased  workload due to demand driven nature of this initiative as well as due to incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the continued implementation of Jordan’s Principle.

planning_explanation:
SPENDING: The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* an increase in funding for the construction and operation of shelters and transition houses for Indigenous women, children and 2SLGBTQQIA+ people; 
* an increase in funding for the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2021); and 
* a decrease in funding for the Family Violence Prevention Program.
variance_explanation:

• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates for the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2023); and
• a transfer to the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs for the Family Violence Prevention Program for self-governing Indigenous governments in the Yukon

FTE:
The variance in FTEs utilization is mainly due to increased support to deliver program funding in the northern regions.

SPENDING:
The difference between 2023-24 Planned Spending and Actual Spending primarily reflects:

• an incremental funding provided through Supplementary Estimates to:
 - maintain the First Nations Child and Family Services Program; and
 - implement reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services Program.

•  the deferral of funding to future years for:
 -  costs related to compensation and for the reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services and Jordan’s Principle programs; and
 - advancing the implementation and operationalization of Indigenous children and family services' laws. These funds could not be spent in 2023-24 and are reprofiled to future years when it would be available for the intended purposes.

FTE:
The increase in FTEs is due to growth related to the implementation of Long Term Reform’s immediate measures resulting from the December 2021 Agreement in Principle, as well as an increase in First Nations exercising jurisdiction under an Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families.

organization: Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada
planning_explanation: Starting in 2023-24, planned spending for the Promotion Program have decreased as an internal reallocation of funds has been made to the Compliance Program due to operational pressures related to the volume of complaints and incident reports.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual resources is mainly due to funding received for the operating budget carry forward exercise, compensation related to the new collective bargaining and adjustments to the employee benefit plans. The increase in expenses is mainly attributed to additional spending on staffing resulting from salary increases, and retroactive payments made following the ratification of collective agreements over the past years.

organization: Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada
planning_explanation: Starting in 2023-24, the planned spending for the Compliance Program has increased to address operational pressures related to  breaches and complaints volumes. The funds were reallocated internally from the Promotion Program and Internal Services.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual resources is mainly due to funding received for the operating budget carry forward from 2022-23 to 2023-24, compensation adjustments to fund salary increases to meet obligations under new collective agreements and the temporary funding received as part of Budget 2023 to reduce the backlog of privacy complaints and to undertake more in-depth investigations of privacy breaches across public and private organizations and to improve response rates to privacy complaints from Canadians.  The increase in expenses is mainly attributed to additional spending on staffing resulting from salary increases, and retroactive payments made following the ratification of collective agreements over the past years.

organization: Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada
core_responsibility: Internal services – Office of the Privacy Commissioner
program_name: Internal Services – Office of the Privacy Commissioner
planning_explanation: Starting in 2023-24, the planned spending for Internal Services have decreased as an internal reallocation of funds has been made to the Compliance Program due to operational pressures related to the volume of complaints and incident reports.
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual resources is mainly due to funding received for the operating budget carry forward exercise, compensation related to the new collective bargaining and adjustments to the employee benefit plans. The increase in expenses is mainly attributed to additional spending on staffing resulting from salary increases, retroactive payments made following the ratification of collective agreements over the past years, as well as an increase in professional services, expenditures for computer equipment and license fees for applications software.

organization: Federal Economic Development Agency for Northern Ontario
planning_explanation: The decrease in 2024-25 from 2023-24 is attributed to the termination of temporary funding announced in Budget 2021 related to the Jobs and Growth Fund and the Aerospace Regional Recovery Initiative and the termination of temporary funding announced in the 2020 Fall Economic Statement related to the Black Entrepreneurship Program.
variance_explanation:
The planned spending was estimated based on historic trends. However, the actual spending showed higher spending in Community Economic Development and Diversification, including for projects impacting under represented groups, was greater than expected and therefore prioritized, which resulted in lower spending in Business Development and Regional Innovation Ecosystem.

The variance in full-time equivalents (FTE) is due to staffing activities at FedNor not progressing as quickly as planned, along with an unanticipated level of staff turnover. These factors collectively contributed to the variance.

organization: Federal Economic Development Agency for Northern Ontario
variance_explanation:

The variance in full-time equivalents (FTE) is due to staffing activities at FedNor not progressing as quickly as planned, along with an unanticipated level of staff turnover. These factors collectively contributed to the variance.

organization: Federal Economic Development Agency for Northern Ontario
planning_explanation: The increase in 2025-26 from 2024-25 is attributed to the completion of an internal transfer with the Department of Industry, Innovation and Economic Development (Internal transfer commenced when FedNor was part of ISED).
variance_explanation:
The planned spending was estimated based on historic trends. However, the actual spending showed higher spending in Community Economic Development, including for projects impacting under represented groups, was greater than expected and therefore prioritized, which resulted in lower spending in Business Development and Regional Innovation Ecosystem.

The variance in full-time equivalents (FTE) is due to staffing activities at FedNor not progressing as quickly as planned, along with an unanticipated level of staff turnover. These factors collectively contributed to the variance.

organization: Federal Economic Development Agency for Northern Ontario
variance_explanation: The variance between planned and actual spending in Internal Services is attributable to differences in the basis used for planning versus actual expense allocation. Planned amounts were determined using FTE counts, which assumed a direct alignment of costs with program activities. However, as FedNor continues to rely on other departments for the provision of Internal Services through Memorandum of Understanding (MOUs) during our transition to becoming a standalone agency, many expenses have been appropriately coded to Internal Services rather than being tied to program-specific FTEs.

planning_explanation: The decrease in planned spending in 2025-26 compared to 2024-25 reflects a decrease in funding for the Youth Employment and Skills Program.
The decrease in planned spending in 2026-27 compared to 2025-26 reflects a decrease in funding for the Dairy Direct Payment Program.

The Canadian Pari-Mutuel Agency's vote-netted revenue, operating costs and Employee Benefit Plan are being adjusted to reflect the forecasts in their 2024-25 to 2026-27 Business Plan. The revenues are generated through the regulation and supervision of pari-mutuel betting on horse racing at racetracks across Canada.

core_responsibility: Regulate and Supervise the Communications System
planning_explanation: The planned spending in 2024-25 is lower than the 2023-24 planned spending by a total of nearly $1.6 million. This decrease is attributable to the sunsetting of temporary funding for the implementation of amendments to the Broadcasting Act (C-11). With the coming into force of amendments to the Broadcasting Act (C-11), the planned expenditures are, from now on, netted by revenues. The planned spending then decreases by $1.8 million in 2025-26 because of the sunsetting of temporary funding for the implementation of the Online News Act (C-18). The planned spending remains at the same level thereafter.

core_responsibility: Regulate and Supervise the Communications System
planning_explanation: The planned spending in 2024-25 exceeds the 2023-24 planned spending by a total of nearly $1.9 million. This increase is attributable to the coming into force of amendments to the Broadcasting Act (C-11), as well as to an increase in planned expenditures in telecommunications-related activities, which decrease by $0.6 million thereafter in 2025-26 to remain at the same level in the following fiscal year.

planning_explanation: The planned spending in 2024-25 is lower than the 2023-24 planned spending by a total of around $1.6 million. This decrease is attributable to the sunsetting of temporary funding for the implementation of amendments to the Broadcasting Act (C-11). With the coming into force of amendments to the Broadcasting Act (C-11), the planned expenditures are, from now on, netted by revenues. The planned spending then decreases by $0.5 million in 2025-26 due to the sunsetting of temporary funding for the implementation of the Online News Act (C-18). The planned spending remains at a similar level thereafter.
The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the ramping down of the current project phase in the Gateway External Robotic Interfaces (GERI).

The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is due to a net decrease of investments in WildFireSat (WFS); as announced in 2022 Budget, additional funding for this initiative is expected to be accessed in the upcoming years.

The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the reduction of the project initiative inside the European Space Agency (ESA) Program. The decrease in planned spending from 2025-26 to 2026-27 is mainly attributable to the ramping down of the current phase in the Quantum Encryption and Science Satellite (QEYSSat) project.

The variation in planned spending is attributable to the Artemis II mission scheduled for September 2025 and the Starliner-1 mission scheduled to launch between 2024 and 2025. The Communications Directorate dedicates some of its resources to these missions.

The variation in planned FTEs is attributable to the Artemis II mission scheduled for September 2025 and the Starliner-1 mission scheduled to launch between 2024 and 2025. The Communications Directorate dedicates some of its resources to these missions.
The variation in planned spending is mainly due to major refurbishment projects at the John H. Chapman Space Center, which are scheduled for completion by the end of 2024-25.

Immigrant and Refugee Selection and Integration
planning_explanation:
**Planned Spending**
The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The phase down of resettlement funding through the 2023-25 Immigration Levels Plan as a result of a decrease in Government Assisted Refugees admissions;
* The phase down of funding for processing and resettlement activities related to Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023; and
* The sunset of funding related to the transitional financial assistance under the measures related to the Canada-Ukraine Authorization for Emergency Travel. 

**Planned FTEs**
The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the phase down of personnel funding for processing and resettlement activities related to Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023.

core_responsibility: Immigrant and Refugee Selection and Integration
planning_explanation:
**Planned Spending**
The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The phase down of funding for the Interim Federal Health Program (IFHP) to cover incremental expenditures related to the provision of healthcare products and services to eligible beneficiaries; and
* The phase down of funding for the higher permanent capacity to process 50,000 claims per year under the in-Canada asylum system (ICAS).

core_responsibility: Immigrant and Refugee Selection and Integration

planning_explanation:
**Planned Spending**
The decrease in planned spending from 2024-25 to 2026-27 is mainly attributable to a decrease in the net operating costs of the Passport Program.

**Planned FTEs**
The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to the decrease of personnel funding for the Passport Program in projects and investments as a results of implementation of current in-flight projects planned for 2024-25.

**Planned Spending**
The decrease in the planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The phase down of information management funding related to Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023; and
* The decrease in temporary funding related to procurement, design and implementation of modernization activities for a client facing platform and pre-implementation activities for future tranches of the Digital Platform Modernization.

**Planned FTEs**
The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The phase down of information management personnel funding related to Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023; and 
* The decrease in temporary personnel funding related to procurement, design and implementation of modernization activities for a client facing platform and pre-implementation activities for future tranches of the Digital Platform Modernization.

**Planned Spending**
The decrease in the planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The decrease in temporary funding related to procurement, design and implementation of modernization activities for a client facing platform and pre-implementation activities for future tranches of the Digital Platform Modernization;
* The phase down of information technology funding related to the immigration and citizenship consultant project; and
* The phase down of information technology funding related to the improvement of client access at the Client Support Centre via telephone, elimination of the email inventory, and reduction of the email response time.

**Planned FTEs**
The decrease in the planned FTEs from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The decrease of information technology personnel funding related to the immigration and citizenship consultant information technology project; 
* The phase down of information technology personnel funding related to the improvement of client access at the Client Support Centre via telephone, elimination of the email inventory, and reduction of the email response time; and
* The decrease in temporary personnel funding related to procurement, design and implementation of modernization activities for a client facing platform and pre-implementation activities for future tranches of the Digital Platform Modernization.

**Planned Spending**
The decrease in the planned spending from 2024-25 to 2025-26 is mainly attributable to:
* The phase down of real property funding related to Canada’s commitment to resettle at least 40,000 Afghan nationals by the end of 2023; and
* The phase down of real property funding related to the improvement of client access at the Client Support Centre via telephone, elimination of the email inventory, and reduction of the email response time.

planning_explanation:
Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending reflects the end of temporary funding for the Canada Digital Adoption Program: Stream 1, the Women's Entrepreneurship Strategy, the Diverse and Inclusive Economy program. Also reflected is the expiry of temporary funding for down of the Small Business Entrepreneurship Development Program in 2025-26.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the expiry of temporary funding for Canada's Digital Adoption Program:  Stream 1.

Variance for planned spending: The increase in planned spending reflects a fluctuation in the approved funding profile of the Universal Broadband Fund which has been adjusted to better align with the actual funding requirements and timelines of the program.  An amount of $1.1 billion was moved from years 2022-23 through 2024-25 to 2025-26 and 2026-27, at which point the funding ends.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the expiry of temporary funding for the Universal Broadband Fund.

Variance for planned spending: The variance in planned spending primarily reflects a decrease in the approved funding profile of the Digital Research Infrastructure Strategy. Also reflected is the expiry of temporary funding for several programs such as Genome Canada, adMare Bioinnovations, Stem Cell Network and the National Artificial Intelligence Institutes.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the end of funding for National Quantum Strategy and due to the Refocusing Government Spending initiative.

Variance for planned spending: The increase in planned spending reflects new funding announced in Budget 2023 under the Strategic Innovation Fund to support battery manufacturing in Canada. This increase is offset by the end of funding for the Canada Digital Adoption Program: Stream 2 and the expiry of temporary funding for Elevate IP and the CAN Health Network. Also reflected are the reductions as part of the Budget 2023 Refocusing Spending exercise.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the expiry of temporary funding for CDAP 2 and due to the Refocusing government spending.
N/A - Variance is less than 10%.

Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending primarily reflects the end of temporary funding to support the Defence Procurement Strategy, which is normally renewed every five years.
N/A - Variance is less than 10%.

Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending reflects the expiry of temporary capital funding received to support the New Generation Wireless Technology (5G) initiative.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the Refocusing Government Spending initiative.
Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending mainly reflects the approved funding profile for Canda Foundation for Sustainable Development Technology.

Variance for planned spending: The variance in planned spending reflects CIPO's intent to contribute to their accumulated surplus instead of drawing on it, as a result of the increase in CIPO revenue following the approval of revised services fees, effective January 1, 2024.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to planned increase under CIPO.

Variance for FTEs: Variance related to expected reduction in staffing levels due to attrition, in alignment with planned savings measures. This is not anticipated to impact the delivery of programs and services to Canadians.

Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending reflects the end of contribution funding for the Indigenous Tourism Fund in 2024-25, after which this activity stabilizes at $3.2 million in operating funding.
Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending mainly reflects the expiry of temporary funding for Mitacs Inc., and the Upskilling for Industry Initiative in 2025-26.

Variance for planned spending: The decrease in planned spending reflects the expiry of temporary funding for Zero Emissions Vehicles and Fuels Regulatory.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the expiry of temporary funding for the Budget 2021 measures entitled Charging and Fueling Zero Emission Vehicles; and Supporting the Production and Use of Clean Fuels.

Variance for FTEs: Variance is due to the need to reorganize our work to generate operational and administrative efficiencies, and by not backfilling certain positions as they vacate through attrition. This is not anticipated to impact the delivery of programs and services to Canadians.

The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period from 2020-21 to 2024-25 to increase access to family justice services in the official language of one’s choice.

The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by year-over-year decreases in grants and contributions funding for (1) Gladue Principles - Systemic and Community-led Responses to Address Overrepresentation of Indigenous People in the Criminal Justice System, and (2) the Implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act.

The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding received over the five-year period from 2020-21 to 2024-25 to increase access to family justice services in the official language of one’s choice.

The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 planned spending is mainly explained by the sunset of temporary contributions funding for (1) Enhancing the Federal Response to Address Gender-Based Violence and Advancing the National Action Plan to End Gender-Based Violence, (2) Funding to Provide Legal Services and Supports for Racialized Communities, and (3) Funding to Support Community Justice Centres.
All legal services resources and expenditures for the Department of Justice Canada are reported under its Legal Services Core Responsibility.
Not applicable - Due to low materiality, the resources and expenditures for Material Management Services are now aligned and reported under Acquisition Management Services.
