planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding level for the Building Safer Communities Fund (BSCF). The decrease in planned funding and planned FTEs from 2025-26 to 2026-27 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the Building Safer Communities Fund (BSCF) and the operating funding for the Initiative to Take Action Against Gun and Gang Violence (ITAAGGV).

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding and planned FTEs from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the delivery to businesses phase of the compensation program for prohibited assault-style firearms. The decrease is also attributable to the maturation of the funding requested to eliminate the Memorial Grant Program (MGP) backlog and accommodate projected near-term growth in program applications . The decrease in planned FTEs from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the operating funding for the Initiative to Take Action Against Gun and Gang Violence (ITAAGGV) and the funding related to enhancing Canada’s firearm control framework under the compensation program for prohibited assault-style firearms.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the Contribution Program to Combat Serious and Organized Crime (CSOC) Drug-Impaired Driving (DID) initiative.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding levels for the First Nation and Inuit Policing Facilities Program (FNIPFP) and the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program (FNIPP). Funding levels are constantly being monitored to ensure that needs are properly supported. The decrease in planned FTEs from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to the maturation of funding for the co-development of First Nations policing legislation and engagement to support Indigenous policing under the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program (FNIPP).

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2024 to 2025 to FY 2025 to 2026 is primarily attributable to the timing of claims and payments for the settlement of existing liabilities for past events under the Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements (DFAA) program. The decrease in planned funding from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to the maturation of the funding for the Humanitarian Workforce (HWF) program and the Canadian Red Cross’s urgent relief efforts to support British Columbia's response and recovery efforts following the 2021 atmospheric flooding and wildfires events.

organization: Department of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness
planning_explanation: The decrease in planned funding from FY 2025 to 2026 to FY 2026 to 2027 is primarily attributable to a decrease in funding for internal services to Enhance Natural Disaster Resilience. The decrease is also due to the maturation of internal services funding for the Building Safer Communities Fund (BSCF), the funding for the Initiative to Take Action Against Gun and Gang Violence (ITAAGGV) and for the co-development of First Nations policing legislation and engagement to support Indigenous policing under the First Nations and Inuit Policing Program (FNIPP).

organization: Economic Development Agency of Canada for the Regions of Quebec
planning_explanation:
The decrease in funding and FTEs over the next fiscal years can be explained by several factors.

1 - The repayable contribution reinvestment mechanism is currently being revised and its authorizations are not included in this Ministerial Plan for the fiscal year 2026-2027.

2 - For fiscal years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026, a reallocation of funds from grants and contributions to the operating budget was carried out in order to stabilize the workforce to ensure follow-ups and other essential activities to close the many emergency and recovery initiatives put in place in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

3 - The effort deployed by the ministry to refocus government spending on main priorities increases annually and results in further reductions in operating expenses.

4 - The Tourism Growth Program, a temporary initiative aimed at helping communities, small and medium-sized businesses and non-profit organizations create local and community tourism projects and events, ends March 31st.

The decrease in 2025-26 planned spending is primarily due to variations in funding for Enhanced Nature Legacy as well as the sunset of funding in 2024-25 to implement the Federal Framework to address the Legacy of Residential Schools. The decrease in 2026-27 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding for the initiatives Enhanced Nature Legacy and implementation of Canada's new marine conservation targets. 

The decrease in 2025-26 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of funding in 2024-25 to implement the Federal Framework to address the Legacy of Residential Schools. The decrease in 2026-27 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of funding for the initiatives Enhanced Nature Legacy and implementation of Canada's new marine conservation targets.

core_responsibility: Protecting and Presenting Canada's Natural and Cultural Heritage
planning_explanation:
The decrease in 2025-26 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of the temporary funding in 2024-25 for investments in Parks Canada’s assets to support transition to long-term asset sustainability. The further decrease in 2026-27 planned spending is primarily due to the sunset of funding for the initiatives Enhanced Nature Legacy, implementation of Canada's new marine conservation targets, address imminent threats to wood bison, and wildfire and flood resilience.

The decrease in 2026-27 planned full-time equivalents is primarily due to the sunset of funding for the initiatives Enhanced Nature Legacy, address imminent threats to wood bison, and wildfire and flood resilience.

planning_explanation: Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for delivering ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources. Reflected in 2024-25 are planned resources for new initiatives from Budget 2023, including the Canadian Dental Care Plan, Building a World-class Health Data System for Canadians and the Action Plan for Official Languages. Funding related to the Canadian Dental Care Plan for 2025-26 has not been secured yet; therefore, it is not reflected in outer years. Funding for cloud operations for 2025-26 is not included in the planned spending because the enterprise-wide funding model is being developed. In the absence of an enterprise-wide funding model by 2025-26, funding will be sourced by Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat resources for that year.

Resources will begin to ramp up and will peak in 2026-27, when the 2026 Census of Population and 2026 Census of Agriculture are conducted. This pattern is typical for the agency because of the cyclical nature of the Census Program.
Statistics Canada is expecting to maintain its capacity in future years for delivering ongoing statistical programs, with no significant shifts in resources.

program_name: Expenditure Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews
planning_explanation:
The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Expenditures Data, Analysis, Results, and Reviews program is mainly attributable to the funding for damages caused by the Phoenix Pay System, which is sunsetting in 2025–26. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

program_name: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives

planning_explanation: The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Public Service Accessibility program is mainly attributable to a reallocation of resources.

The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Comptrollership program is mainly attributable to funding to advance clean fuels markets and carbon capture, utilization, and storage technologies in Canada and a reduction in transfers to various organizations to support projects which will reduce greenhouse gas emissions in federal government operations.

The decrease of full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding from the National Research Council of Canada to TBS for the implementation of a buy clean secretariat for federal procurement (sunsetting in 2025–26), funding for the federal contaminated sites action plan (sunsetting in 2024–25), and funding to increase opportunities in federal procurement for Indigenous-led businesses (sunsetting in 2024–25). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Digital Government program is mainly attributable to funding to provide continued leadership in cloud governance to help departments in their transition to cloud technologies, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.

The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Public Service Employer Payments program is mainly attributable to the funding requirements for the public service insurance plans and programs.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Employer program is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service (sunsetting in 2024–25) and funding for the action plan for Black public servants (sunsetting in 2026–27). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2025–26 for the Regulatory Policy, Oversight, and Cooperation program is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding for the extension of targeted regulatory reviews and external advisory committee on regulatory competitiveness, which is sunsetting in 2024–25. The initiative is subject to the renewal process.
The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Management and Oversight Services program is mainly attributable to budget reductions.

The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Communications program is mainly attributable to the decrease in funding for the extension of targeted regulatory reviews, external advisory committee on regulatory competitiveness and the regulators’ capacity fund, and funding to address workplace harassment, discrimination and violence in the federal public service, which all sunset in 2024–25. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.

The decrease of planned spending and full-time equivalents from 2024–25 to 2025–26 for the Legal Services program is mainly attributable to the reduction in funding to address workplace harassment, discrimination and violence in the federal public service and funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service, which both sunset in 2024–25. All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
The increase of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Financial Management Services program is attributable to funding for collective agreements.

The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Information Management Services program is mainly attributable to decreased funding for implementing proactive pay equity in the federal public service (sunsetting in 2024–25) and funding for the action plan for Black public servants (sunsetting in 2025–26). All initiatives are subject to the renewal process.
The decrease of planned spending from 2024–25 to 2026–27 for the Information Technology Services program is mainly attributable to budget reductions.

Planned spending for appeals is expected to increase due to funding received to address increased demand for review and appeal services. 

Planned human resources for appeals are expected to increase due to funding received to address increased demand for review and appeal services.

program_name: Public Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* a net decrease in funding for the Indigenous Early Learning and Child Care Transformation Initiative, including transfers with the Department of Employment and Social Development.

FTE: 
The variance in FTEs primarily reflect : 
* the sunsetting of Budget 2021 funding for Mental Health and Wellness and funding to implement the Federal framework to address the legacy of residential schools and Anti-Indigenous Racism, as well as an allocation of resources from this program to meet program needs and priorities.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for the Assisted Living Program.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect: 
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for primary care (Budget 2021).

FTE:
* The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 is mainly due to funding received under Budget 2022 for Human Health Resources.
* The variance between 2025-26 and 2026-27 is mainly due to the sunsetting of Budget 2021.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* net decrease in funding associated with the First Nations Health Authority.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding due to an internal transfer for the First Nations Health Authority in 2024-25.

program_name: Jordan's Principle and the Inuit Child First Initiative
planning_explanation:
SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* decrease in funding for the continued implementation of Jordan's Principle and Inuit Child First Initiative.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 and 2025-26 in FTE utilization is mainly due to the sunset in Program Integrity piece of Funding for continued Implementation of Jordan's Principle (Budget 2023).

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding for the Pathways to Safe Indigenous Communities Initiative (Budget 2021). 

FTE:
The variance in FTEs is due to sunset of funding to support Indigenous policing and community safety.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for implementation reforms to the First Nations Child and Family Services Program.

FTE:
The variance is due to the sunset of :
* Funding to advance implementation of _An Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_, including a new grant program (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding to implement the Cowessess First Nation’s child and family services law, “Miyo Pimatisowin Act” and, Funding to implement _An Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_ (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding to support the implementation of the _Act respecting First Nations, Inuit and Métis children, youth and families_ and ongoing reform of Indigenous Child and Family Services (at the end of 2024-25).
* Funding for First Nations Child and Family Services; Canadian Human Rights Tribunal Orders Implementation; and Non-compliance Motion Settlement (at the end of 2025-26).

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* annual growth;
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to strengthen employment and skills for youth; and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for income assistance, case management, and pre-employment supports to individuals and family living on reserve.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for urban, rural, and northern Indigenous housing projects (Budget 2022 and Budget 2023); 
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding for the Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples Program; and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding fo infrastructure in Indigenous communities (Budget 2021).

FTE:
Significant reduction in FTEs after 2024-25 is due to:
* sunsetting Infrastructure Funding for Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples Service Providers (Budget 2019);
* Funding for Indigenous infrastructure projects (Budget 2021); and 
* Funding Urban Programming for Indigenous Peoples (Budget 2022).

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* annual growth; and
* an increase in funding for the core funding refinements of elementary and secondary education (Budget 2021).

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to strengthen employment and skills for youth;
* annual growth; and 
* an increase in funding to support First Nations, Inuit and Métis Nation post-secondary students and to develop regional post-secondary strategies for First Nations (Budget 2019).

FTE:
The reduction of 9 FTEs in 2025-26 versus 2024-25 is mainly due to the sunsetting of the Funding to strengthen employment and skills supports for youth.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect the one-time investment in the Northern Ontario Grid Connection Project.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2026-27 is due to sunsetting of Budget 2021 and 2022 Fall Economic Statements.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* an increase in funding for infrastructure projects in Indigenous communities;
* an increase in funding for First Nations land management; and
* a transfer from the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs for the Federal Contaminated Sites Action Plan in 2024-25.

FTE:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2025-26 is due to a decrease in FTEs due to the sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for Additions to Reserve Land for First Nations Economic Recovery (Budget 2021) and the Federal Contaminated Site Action Plan: Phase IV.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to reimburse First Nations and emergency management service providers for on-reserve response and recovery activities.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* a transfer from the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs in 2024-25 and 2025-26 to help advance reconciliation and establish a new relationship with the Mohawks of Kahnawà:ke.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2025-26) of funding to increase federal procurement from Indigenous-led businesses.

FTEs:
The variance between 2024-25 to 2026-27 is due to sunsetting of FTEs previously funded for creating additional opportunities in federal procurement.

SPENDING:
The year-over-year differences primarily reflect:
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to adjust the new fiscal relationship grant for inflation and population growth (Budget 2021); and
* sunset (at the end of 2024-25) of funding to implement phase one of a transformational approach to Indigenous data (Budget 2021).

FTE:
The variance of FTEs is due to:
* sunset of Funding for Strengthening Governance and Advancing the New Fiscal Relationship with First Nations, and Enhancing Initiatives of the First Nations Financial Management Board.
* sunset of Funding to implement phase one of a transformational approach to Indigenous data.
* sunset of Funding to Implement the Expedited Resolution Strategy for Agricultural Benefits Claims.
